lessons.title: What is Blockchain?
lessons.content:
A blockchain is a distributed digital ledger that records transactions across many computers. Think of it like a notebook that everyone can read, but no one can erase or change what's already written.

Key characteristics:
‚Ä¢ Decentralized - No single entity controls it
‚Ä¢ Transparent - All transactions are visible
‚Ä¢ Immutable - Once recorded, data cannot be altered
‚Ä¢ Secure - Uses cryptography to protect data
keyTakeaways: Blockchain is a digital ledger distributed across many computers
Data on blockchain is transparent and cannot be changed
No central authority controls the blockchain

lessons.title: Understanding Decentralization
lessons.content:
Decentralization means spreading power and control across many people instead of one central authority. In traditional systems, banks control your money. In crypto, you control it yourself.

Benefits of decentralization:
‚Ä¢ No single point of failure
‚Ä¢ Resistant to censorship
‚Ä¢ Greater privacy and control
‚Ä¢ Lower fees (no middleman)
‚Ä¢ 24/7 availability
keyTakeaways: Decentralization removes the need for intermediaries
You have full control over your assets
More resistant to censorship and shutdowns

lessons.title: What is Bitcoin?
lessons.content:
Bitcoin is the first and most well-known cryptocurrency, created in 2009 by an anonymous person (or group) known as Satoshi Nakamoto. It's often called 'digital gold' because of its limited supply.

Key facts:
‚Ä¢ Maximum supply: 21 million coins
‚Ä¢ Used for peer-to-peer transactions
‚Ä¢ Secured by proof-of-work mining
‚Ä¢ Decentralized and borderless
keyTakeaways: Bitcoin was the first cryptocurrency
Limited to 21 million coins total
Operates without banks or governments

lessons.title: What is Ethereum?
lessons.content:
Ethereum is a blockchain platform that enables smart contracts and decentralized applications (dApps). While Bitcoin is digital money, Ethereum is a programmable blockchain.

Key features:
‚Ä¢ Smart contracts - Self-executing code
‚Ä¢ dApps - Decentralized applications
‚Ä¢ NFT marketplace foundation
‚Ä¢ DeFi platform base
‚Ä¢ ETH cryptocurrency for transactions
keyTakeaways: Ethereum enables smart contracts and dApps
More versatile than Bitcoin
Powers most NFTs and DeFi applications

lessons.title: Understanding Altcoins
lessons.content:
Altcoins are any cryptocurrencies other than Bitcoin. The term comes from 'alternative coins'. There are thousands of altcoins, each with different purposes and features.

Popular altcoin categories:
‚Ä¢ Platform coins (Ethereum, Solana)
‚Ä¢ Stablecoins (USDC, USDT)
‚Ä¢ Meme coins (Dogecoin, Shiba Inu)
‚Ä¢ Privacy coins (Monero, Zcash)
‚Ä¢ Utility tokens (specific use cases)
keyTakeaways: Altcoins are all cryptocurrencies except Bitcoin
Each serves different purposes
Research before investing in any altcoin

lessons.title: What is DeFi?
lessons.content:
DeFi (Decentralized Finance) refers to financial services built on blockchain technology. It recreates traditional financial systems like lending, borrowing, and trading without banks.

DeFi services:
‚Ä¢ Lending and borrowing
‚Ä¢ Decentralized exchanges (DEXs)
‚Ä¢ Yield farming
‚Ä¢ Liquidity pools
‚Ä¢ Staking rewards
keyTakeaways: DeFi removes middlemen from financial services
Open 24/7 with no geographical restrictions
Higher risk but potentially higher returns

lessons.title: Understanding Smart Contracts
lessons.content:
Smart contracts are self-executing programs stored on a blockchain. When certain conditions are met, the contract automatically executes. No lawyers or intermediaries needed!

How they work:
‚Ä¢ Written in code (usually Solidity)
‚Ä¢ Deployed to blockchain
‚Ä¢ Execute automatically when triggered
‚Ä¢ Cannot be changed once deployed
‚Ä¢ Transparent and verifiable
keyTakeaways: Smart contracts execute automatically
Remove the need for intermediaries
Form the basis of DeFi and dApps

lessons.title: Liquidity Pools Explained
lessons.content:
Liquidity pools are collections of cryptocurrencies locked in smart contracts. They enable decentralized trading by providing the funds needed for exchanges.

How they work:
‚Ä¢ Users deposit pairs of tokens
‚Ä¢ Traders swap tokens from the pool
‚Ä¢ Liquidity providers earn fees
‚Ä¢ Automated market makers set prices
‚Ä¢ Risk of impermanent loss
keyTakeaways: Liquidity pools enable decentralized trading
Providers earn fees from trades
Understand impermanent loss before providing liquidity

lessons.title: What are NFTs?
lessons.content:
NFT stands for Non-Fungible Token. Unlike cryptocurrencies where each coin is identical, NFTs are unique digital items. They prove ownership of digital or physical assets on the blockchain.

Common NFT uses:
‚Ä¢ Digital art
‚Ä¢ Collectibles
‚Ä¢ Gaming items
‚Ä¢ Music and videos
‚Ä¢ Real estate deeds
‚Ä¢ Membership passes
keyTakeaways: NFTs are unique, non-interchangeable tokens
Prove ownership of digital assets
Stored on blockchain for authenticity

lessons.title: NFT Marketplaces
lessons.content:
NFT marketplaces are platforms where you can buy, sell, and trade NFTs. Each marketplace has its own features, fees, and supported blockchains.

Popular marketplaces:
‚Ä¢ OpenSea - Largest NFT marketplace
‚Ä¢ Rarible - Community-owned
‚Ä¢ Magic Eden - Solana-focused
‚Ä¢ Blur - Pro trader platform
‚Ä¢ Foundation - Curated art
keyTakeaways: Multiple marketplaces exist for trading NFTs
Each has different fees and features
Always verify authenticity before buying

lessons.title: Crypto Exchanges Explained
lessons.content:
Cryptocurrency exchanges are platforms where you can buy, sell, and trade crypto. There are two main types: centralized (CEX) and decentralized (DEX).

Centralized exchanges:
‚Ä¢ Operated by companies (Coinbase, Binance)
‚Ä¢ Easy to use for beginners
‚Ä¢ Higher liquidity
‚Ä¢ Require KYC verification

Decentralized exchanges:
‚Ä¢ No central authority
‚Ä¢ You control your keys
‚Ä¢ No KYC required
‚Ä¢ More complex to use
keyTakeaways: CEXs are easier but you don't control your keys
DEXs give you full control but are more complex
Choose based on your comfort level and needs

lessons.title: Understanding Market Orders
lessons.content:
Market orders are the simplest type of trade. You buy or sell at the current market price immediately. Great for quick trades, but the price might change slightly before execution.

Order types:
‚Ä¢ Market order - Execute immediately at current price
‚Ä¢ Limit order - Set your desired price
‚Ä¢ Stop-loss - Automatic sell at specific price
‚Ä¢ Take-profit - Automatic sell when target reached
keyTakeaways: Market orders execute immediately
Limit orders let you set your price
Use stop-losses to manage risk

lessons.title: Technical Analysis Basics
lessons.content:
Technical analysis involves studying price charts and patterns to predict future movements. Traders use indicators and chart patterns to make decisions.

Common indicators:
‚Ä¢ Moving averages
‚Ä¢ RSI (Relative Strength Index)
‚Ä¢ MACD (Moving Average Convergence Divergence)
‚Ä¢ Support and resistance levels
‚Ä¢ Volume analysis
keyTakeaways: Technical analysis uses historical data
Many indicators exist to help predict trends
Not foolproof - use with other research

lessons.title: Crypto Wallets Explained
lessons.content:
A crypto wallet stores your private keys (passwords) that give you access to your cryptocurrency. Not your keys, not your crypto!

Wallet types:
‚Ä¢ Hot wallets - Connected to internet (MetaMask, Trust Wallet)
‚Ä¢ Cold wallets - Offline storage (Ledger, Trezor)
‚Ä¢ Paper wallets - Keys written on paper
‚Ä¢ Custodial - Exchange holds your keys
‚Ä¢ Non-custodial - You control your keys
keyTakeaways: Wallets store your private keys, not actual crypto
Cold wallets are most secure
Never share your private keys or seed phrase

lessons.title: Avoiding Scams
lessons.content:
The crypto space has many scams. Being aware of common tactics can protect your funds.

Common scams:
‚Ä¢ Phishing websites and emails
‚Ä¢ Fake giveaways
‚Ä¢ Pump and dump schemes
‚Ä¢ Rug pulls (fake projects)
‚Ä¢ Romance scams
‚Ä¢ Fake customer support
keyTakeaways: Never share private keys or seed phrases
Verify URLs carefully before connecting wallet
If it sounds too good to be true, it probably is

lessons.title: Two-Factor Authentication
lessons.content:
Two-factor authentication (2FA) adds an extra security layer to your accounts. Even if someone gets your password, they can't access your account without the second factor.

Types of 2FA:
‚Ä¢ Authenticator apps (Google Authenticator, Authy)
‚Ä¢ SMS codes (less secure)
‚Ä¢ Hardware keys (YubiKey)
‚Ä¢ Biometric (fingerprint, face ID)
keyTakeaways: Always enable 2FA on exchange accounts
Authenticator apps are more secure than SMS
Keep backup codes in a safe place

lessons.title: Web3 and the Future
lessons.content:
Web3 represents the next evolution of the internet, built on blockchain technology. Instead of big tech companies owning your data, you do.

Web3 features:
‚Ä¢ Decentralized ownership
‚Ä¢ Token-based economics
‚Ä¢ User-owned data
‚Ä¢ Permissionless innovation
‚Ä¢ Interoperable platforms
keyTakeaways: Web3 gives users control of their data
Built on blockchain and crypto principles
Still evolving but growing rapidly

lessons.title: Layer 2 Solutions
lessons.content:
Layer 2 solutions are built on top of existing blockchains to improve speed and reduce costs. They handle transactions off the main chain, then settle on the main chain.

Popular Layer 2s:
‚Ä¢ Polygon - Ethereum scaling
‚Ä¢ Arbitrum - Optimistic rollup
‚Ä¢ Optimism - Another rollup solution
‚Ä¢ Lightning Network - Bitcoin scaling
‚Ä¢ zkSync - Zero-knowledge rollup
keyTakeaways: Layer 2s improve blockchain scalability
Faster and cheaper than Layer 1
Maintain security of main blockchain

lessons.title: The Metaverse and Crypto
lessons.content:
The metaverse is a collective virtual shared space where users can interact. Cryptocurrency and NFTs enable the metaverse economy.

Metaverse use cases:
‚Ä¢ Virtual real estate
‚Ä¢ Digital fashion and items
‚Ä¢ Virtual events and concerts
‚Ä¢ Play-to-earn games
‚Ä¢ Social interactions
‚Ä¢ Virtual workspaces
keyTakeaways: Metaverse combines VR with blockchain
NFTs enable ownership of virtual items
Growing market with major investments

lessons.title: Consensus Mechanisms
lessons.content:
Consensus mechanisms are how blockchains agree on the state of the network. They ensure all nodes have the same data without a central authority.

Main types:
‚Ä¢ Proof of Work (PoW) - Mining-based
‚Ä¢ Proof of Stake (PoS) - Staking-based
‚Ä¢ Delegated Proof of Stake (DPoS)
‚Ä¢ Proof of Authority (PoA)
‚Ä¢ Practical Byzantine Fault Tolerance (PBFT)
keyTakeaways: Consensus mechanisms validate transactions
PoW uses energy, PoS uses staked coins
Each has trade-offs in security and speed
